reviewText: First off, let me tell you something important: Parents, let your kids watch this. Kids, you will probably like this movie. Next, I'd like to tell everyone else: Unless you are 12, haven't finished sixth grade, or maybe got into some sort of accident that limits your reasoning and logic skills... you won't want to sit through this.As for the 'story', it goes like this:Maggie Payton (Lindsay Lohan) is the daughter of the famous Ray Payton, race car driver. She has just graduated college, and plans to take an internship at ESPN in New York. Of course, before she can leave, her dad gives her a grad gift. It's her pick of any car from Crazy Dave's Junkyard. Dave has just acquired a car that doesn't seem to like him much, and appears eager to get rid of it. It's a '63 bug. Maggie walks right by the bug and picks a Nissan. However, Herbie gets his chance to 'squash' the opposition, and Maggie settles on the crappiest car in the lot. The bug. She drives it off (which is strange for a 40 year old car in a junk yard... also, it has a perfect interior?) to the mechanic, who just happens to be high school friend Kevin. But, before she arrives at the garage, she finds a note inside of the glove box telling her the car is... Herbie. And that he has the power to make her feel happy, or something. After the garage, Maggie and Kevin take out Herbie. And he pisses off a Nascar Champion (Trip Murphey-Matt Dillon). They race him in Herbie, and of course Herbie does a backflip and spins on his back bumper or some other ridiculous move that has made Herbie famous. After a race montage, Maggie and Kevin make an enemy, and begin to realize Herbie has a mind of his own. After another 3 minute montage, Herbie is good as new. They see a newspaper ad for the Trip Murphy Challenge and Maggie must choose between an internship and racing, but her dad (Ray-Mike Keaton)(who, even though he, his father and his son Ray Jr. are all Nascar racers and she was an accomplished street racer in high school) doesn't want her racing, and gets all huffy when she does. This leads to some more montages and stuff happens till some form of happy ending.The movie takes it upon itself to see how many montages it can use to accomplish the story. By my count, it was more than six. Let me list them, if you don't believe me.-The intro-First Repair scene-First Race-Second Race-Second Repair-Monster Truck scene-Third RacePlus, many other scenes feature cut-away clips and retro music which classifies them as montage-esque scenes at least. It's hard to believe there is any story at all, but I guess the director just wanted to make sure no one remembered it. In fact, I think 'Walkin on sunshine' is the only part I remember.Special featues are present, but they suck. An audio track with Director Angela Robinson grates on your nerve, about how much she loved the old films, how great this actor was, or how hard the hydraulics were to get right there. Boring ass kissing. Next, Bloopers, most of which are flubbed lines. Some deleted scenes which were cut for redundancy or time, but all of them are crap, even kids would have been bogged down by these if they stayed.A featurette titled 'A day at the races' hosted by Nascars own Deborah Renshaw. This just walks you through a day in the life of a driver, and why they love driving. The next two featurettes are about the car itself: "Breaking the rules:The stunts of herbie", and "Bringing Herbie to life". The first covers how they had all kinds of cars and hydraulics etc., and the crazy driving. There was a stunt car, so the real herbie didn't get hurt, and don't worry, the hard stunts were left up to the magical CG cars. The next one is more of a making of, but it is short, and was probably on disney channel at one point. Lastly, we get a music video of Lindsay Lohan's 'First', a music video (or.. montage!) about believing in cars to win the race of life... at least, that how I translated it.It's nice to know that Mike Keaton, Matt Dillon and Breckin Myer are getting second billing to a car that can't drive half the stunts, and relies on CG to back up it's already dumb stunts. If you saw a commercial for it you should know it's dumb and dull. Just listen to this:Announcer-Maggie Payton must drive to save her familyLohan-"But dad, I'm a Payton, racings in my blood!"Ann.- With the help of a very special car! *beep beep* Herbie!OK, I work at a video store and have to hear this everyday. But, what is she saving her family from? And how can a CG smartass of a car help her? Maybe she just has to... I don't know, believe in herself or something.Overall, the only reason to watch this is if your enjoying going to grade school, have a Lohan fetish, or enjoy watching Star Wars for R2-D2 (which is basically what Herbie is- He has the power to invent new powers on the spot), then get it. Parents, choose Winn-Dixie, The Incredibles, or even Little Einsteins before this disneys blunder (speaking of disney, this and sky high came out back to back... and herbie barely made back it's budget. Sky High? Made double, for a movie no one even cared about. Sad really...

reviewText: Not only is this a typical Disney movie, it's even a (more-or-less) typical Herbie movie.  For some strange reason, director Robinson used some techniques (in my opinion, anyways) from the 1980s - multiple split-screens, Herbie red-white-and-blue ribbons for segues, even music from Van Halen, Loverboy and Pilot.  I'm inclined to think they came from her personal music collection.  I'm not sure what the point was, except to show the movie picking up where the last Herbie left off.  The movie even begins with newpaper clippings and film clips of the previous Herbie movies, followed by stories of Herbie going into decline, losing races, and then ending up in a junkyard - much to the consternation of the junkyard owner!I think the cast pretty much acquitted themselves here.  I don't know too much about Lindsay Lohan (I'm not into celebrity gossip), but I didn't see anything glaringly wrong with her performance.  Matt Dillon makes for an interesting villain, barely managing not to sneer TOO much at the heroes.  Even Michael Keaton came off OK.One critic mentioned that there's a lot of corporate placement in this movie.  If you think about it, isn't that what NASCAR is really all about - securing sponsors?  There are even several scenes where the characters agonize over losing their sponsors.  Did director Robinson put all the products in there merely to pay the bills, or to also make a point about corporate sponsorship of NASCAR?  I'd like to think the latter.Overall, it's still a great family film.  (In fact, there was a birthday party of 8-year olds behind me in the theatre, having a great time.)Hey, there are worse ways to spend your summer!

reviewText: Lindsay Lohan is a young actress with a mostly teenage following and in this movie, "Herbie: Fully Loaded" she stretches her audience appeal downward, to the younger age crowd. She stars in this film as a young woman about to graduate from college who has many things on her career plate, but wants more than anything to drive race cars. The family tree has many NASCAR racers, and Lindsay's character wants to continue this legacy even though her father is uneasy with the idea.This movie is based on the old "Herbie" movies and television series from the past. The Volkswagen bug with the mind of a human is the centerpiece of this film and he plays a major part in the movie's final outcome. One thing that I expected to be different was the appearance of Herbie. Considering this is the year 2005, I expected to see dazzling special effects that would make Herbie look and act more like a person. But the director resisted the urge to add excessive special effects and instead chose to make Herbie more of a car than a person. I'm glad this decision was made, because the movie would have too surreal otherwise. There is maybe one or two scenes where the special effects are strong. Other than that, Herbie looks like an ordinary Volkswagen bug.There is a little bit of humor to be found in this film, but it is the type that will appeal mostly to the 5 to 15 year- old crowd. There are scenes where Herbie displays his anger by spraying people with automotive fluids and some mildly funny scenes were Herbie falls in love with another Volkswagen bug. This is it for the funny stuff and unless you're less than fifteen years of age, you will likely not find it all that amusing.The soundtrack from this film included many old songs from the 1970 to 1985 era, like "Jump" by Van Halen, "Hello" by Lionel Ritchie, and covers of old tunes like "Born to be Wild" and "Roll on Down the Highway". I like most of these songs, but they didn't seem to fit together very well for this movie. When I listened to these songs in the movie, I invariably started to wonder why a different song wasn't selected with the majority of the scenes. These aren't bad songs by any means but I can think of many tunes that would have made for a better soundtrack.Overall, this movie is simple and flat, without much of a plot and without anything terribly memorable- both in its storyline and in its performances. It's generally very predictable, too, with few surprises if any. But I'm going to give it a small recommendation regardless. It is lacking overall, but it makes for some good, clean family entertainment- the type of movie you can take any family member to see (It was given a "G" rating- something you don't see much nowadays), regardless of age, without feeling guilty.

reviewText: One of the first movies I saw when I first came to the US was Herbie Goes To Monte Carlo, at a drive-in when we were living in Livermore, CA.  Since then, there has been a connection between the family, more through my brother, with that gutsy VW Bug with a mind and heart of its own, that blazed a trail through four movies.  In fact, racing excerpts from those movies are shown in the opening sequences of Herbie-Fully Loaded, which has the famed racing Bug resurrected for the current generation.Fully Loaded finds the famed Bug ready to be turned to scrap metal at Crazy Dave's scrapyard.  He is rescued by Maggie Peyton (Lindsay Lohan), whose family has racing in their blood, as her grandfather's a racing legend.  Her father is as well, and is trying to groom his son Ray Jr. to succeed him, but a series of crashes at the race track as well as a dearth of sponsors, dwindling by the minute, makes that impossible.  Maggie though, had her own racing days in high school, and finds her true calling other than going to New York behind the racing scenes.She gains an enemy in macho NASCAR champion Trip Murphy, played by Matt Dillon, when the ever-sensitive Herbie takes offense to one of Murphy's insults to him and scrapes the star's car with his rearview mirror.  This leads to a race where Herbie beats Murphy, to the delight and surprise of the local racing fans.Maggie's reaction to Herbie, pop-eyes and screams, as the VW shows her what he's made of, is akin to what every kid might have if a car did its own thing.  Gradually, she recognizes that Herbie has a soul, as does her school friend Kevin, who runs a garage, and takes a liking to the car.  She does learn of Herbie's sensitivity, when the car, hurt at something she says during another race with Trip, deliberately loses.  This is nothing new, as in The Love Bug, when Jim Douglas, agrees to give up Herbie for a Lancia, only to find an enraged and betrayed Herbie ramming the Lancia.  Herbie fuels Maggie's desire to race again, but her father (Michael Keaton) isn't keen on his daughter suffering injuries or even getting killed on the track, and forbids it.Unlike the other movies, Herbie's headlights move, lowering down when depressed, as does his front bumper.  And yes, he still does squirt oil at anyone mean.  The corporate sponsors and video game tie-ins (Trip's new game) make this up to date for this generation.  And when Herbie sees one of the new Bugs, a bright yellow one, Maggie says, "Herbie, I think she's too young for you."As if remembering what Herbie's main passion was, it was a good move to show this as a racing picture per The Love Bug and Herbie Goes To Monte Carlo, and as such, the racing scenes are the best part of the picture, as is a scene when Herbie takes on a monster truck driven by a nasty thug at a car crash derby, set to Van Halen's "Jump."  The names of Ray Peyton and Ray Peyton Jr. have syllabic similarities to another racing family-think Al Unser and Al Unser Jr.  And having Maggie at the wheel also brings into mind Shirley Muldowney.It's also great having two 80's film stars, Michael Keaton and Matt Dillon back in prominent roles.  And mark this as one of Lindsay Lohan's better films along with the Parent Trap.I still say The Love Bug's the best movie in the Herbie series, but Fully Loaded takes Herbie back to his roots without too much radical updating, and is better than Herbie Goes Bananas, so as such, it qualifies.  Those who grew up on Herbie will definitely enjoy it.

reviewText: When you start talking about making a new Herbie movie, you're messing with my childhood - so you'd better do the job right.  Happily, I think Disney did do it right with Herbie: Fully Loaded; this Herbie fan is happy with it, anyway.  They retained the look and ably captured the heart of that little VW Bug, and that was the secret to success.  Sure, Herbie's vamped up a little bit to race in the NASCAR event at the end, but he's still the same old Love Bug we knew and loved decades ago.  It was somewhat painful for me to see the poor guy reduced to a forgotten legend mere seconds away from being crushed forever in a scrap yard, but Herbie's always been a master of last-second heroics.  I also have to point out that Herbie is a great actor; he can't talk, but you always know how he is feeling.  There are some human actors in Hollywood that could learn a lot about body language and self-expression from watching Herbie do his thing.As I mentioned, Herbie's legendary racing career has been completely forgotten, leaving him forgotten and alone and about to be sent to that great junkyard in the sky.  Then Maggie Peyton (Lindsay Lohan) comes along looking for a car and manages to save him in the nick of time.  She's in for quite a surprise when the car takes her for her first ride - right to an old high school friend (Kevin, played by Justin Long, who does suffer from just a touch of David Schwimmer-itis) now running a garage, and then all the way to a big car expo featuring Nextel champion driver Trip Murphy (Matt Dillon).  Everyone there makes fun of Herbie, but he has the last laugh after he challenges Trip to an impromptu race.  This only renews Maggie's desire to follow in the Peyton family's racing footsteps, but she has to keep her identity a secret because her dad (Michael Keaton) refuses to let her race.It is a formulaic movie; there's no doubt about that.  Both Herbie and Maggie have to hit bottom in order for both of them to get back up and go after what they want.  You've got the disapproving dad and the daughter dedicated to pursuing her lifelong goal, the nascent romance between Maggie and Kevin, and of course the villain who has to be put in his place.  Herbie does it all in style, though, even using his signature move at the end of the big NASCAR race.  Without a Buddy Hackett or a Don Knotts, it's not quite as funny as the classic Herbie films, but Herbie: Fully Loaded does a great job of reintroducing the Love Bug to a whole new generation of fans.  Sports fans will also get a kick out of cameos by Stuart Scott, BP (Benny Parsons to those who don't follow NASCAR), Jeff Gordon (who even tries to act), Dale Jarrett, Tony Stewart (who, for once, doesn't wreck anybody), Jimmie Johnson, and probably some others I've forgotten.I was happy to see the filmmakers throw in some little stuff that almost invisibly makes the movie better (it's those little things that really bring Herbie to life)  - Herbie's wiper blade salute during the national anthem, for example.  You also have a little budding romance for Herbie himself (who apparently likes 'em young), as there's this cute little number that really sets Herbie's radiator boiling.Of course, the best thing about Herbie: Fully Loaded is the fact that it marks a return to the good old days of G-rated family films that everyone can watch and enjoy together.  And all you parents out there, try and get hold of the classic Herbie films; if your kids enjoyed this one, they will absolutely love the old ones.
summary: A triumphant return for the Love Bug

The second is an attempt to smarten up simple films to provide logical explanations to events. This film follows the latter path.Don't get me wrong, it is quite eye-pleasing to see the internal workings of Herbie to explain his magnificent feats, but it does not make it any more believable.In the beginning of this film, we have a college graduate, Maggie Peyton (Lohan), who comes home to find her family's business is going down the tubes (NASCAR racing). At the same time, Herbie is about to be flatten and become a hunk of trash. Fortunately, he is saved when he is purchased by Maggie.As with the older Love Bug movies, Herbie has a mind of his own and ends up getting Maggie in a lot of trouble, most of it surrounding Trip Murphy, the current NASCAR hero.You've seen the previews I am sure and I doubt it would ruin the film to let you know who wins ... but I won't.The film is rather inane and focused on an unrealistic warm and fuzzy feeling. But, with the help of the lovable, sentient, and willful Number 53, Maggie goes up against her nemesis Trip Murphy (another great villain turn by Matt Dillon).Though updated with a modern sensibility, Herbie: Fully Loaded is still a nostalgic, feel-good throwback to those innocent, classic family comedies of yesteryear. In it, we find the Lovebug in a scrapyard, doomed to be compacted.  Maggie Payton (Lindsay Lohan) has recently returned from college and her dad (Michael Keaton) decides to by her something to knock around in until her sports reporting career takes off. reviewText: The Herbie in "Herbie: Fully Loaded" is indeed the original Love Bug, as is made clear during the opening credits when we see some of his best moments from "The Love Bug," "Herbie Rides Again," "Herbies Goes to Monte Carlo," "Herbies Goes Bananas," and "Herbie, the Love Bug."  Actually, I do not know if all of these films are accounted for, or if the made for television version of "The Love Bug" is there as well.  The key thing is the Herbie that Lindsay Lohan drives in this 2005 Disney comedy is the same one that Dean Jones first drove in 1968, albeit now "fully loaded."  That means that the 21st century version of the Love Bug is much more animated, in an anthropormorphic sense more than anything else.But what I found interesting was that even though this is clearly the original Herbie nobody in the movie ever actually notices.  You would think that if a 1963 Volkswagen Beetle won all those races shown in all those headlines during the opening credits when Herbie starts racing again somebody would notice, especially if at the heart of this story you have a racing family like the Peytons.  In a world where people still talk about the 1927 New York Yankees, Jesse Owens at the Berlin Olympics, and Joe Namath winning the Super Bowl, people are going to remember a VW Beetle that goes 200 miles per hour (remember the billboards of the Beetle with a cop giving it a speeding ticket and the caption, "They said it couldn't be done"?).  Consequently, we not sure why this has to be the same Herbie or why he let himself end up in a junk yard beyond a cryptic note in his glove compartment that tells us nothing.Herbie's new owner is Maggie Peyton (Lohan), the daughter in the third generation of a racing family headed by Ray Peyton, Sr. (Michael Keaton) that is getting less than stellar results from Maggie's brother, "In the Way" Ray, Jr. (Breckin Meyer), leaving it to the arrogant Trip Murphy (Matt Dillon) to win all the races.  That is until Herbie enters the picture and if you did not know there was going to be a big race at the end of this one you simply do not appreciate the by the numbers school of American filmmaking.  Dad does not want Maggie to race, she is oblivious to the feelings of her friend and mechanic Kevin (Justin Long), and Herbie participates in a demolition derby on the eve of the big race, but audiences should not worry about any of those things.  Basically the younger you are the more you will enjoy this patently predictable underdog sports movie.  If anything, the simplistic puppy love romantic subplot reinforces that the target audience is a lot younger than the (human) star of the movie.The only real surprise is that this is much more Herbie's movie than it is Lindsay Lohan, who must be reaching the end of her reign as a Disney princess.  All she is basically required to do in this one is scream periodically as Herbie shifts gears.  The Love Bug wins the cuteness battle with his infatuation for the newer VW on the block, plus Herbie is able to do some pretty neat stunts through the use of 21st century special effects (practical and not CGI for the most part) that kids will like.  Besides, it is getting increasingly difficult to cast Lohan in Disney films given her tabloid exploits and her full throttle attempt to grow up, as evidenced by not only her cover shot for "Entertainment Weekly" but the song "First" that she does for this film (listen to the first line of the chorus of the song and think of what other context besides sporting competitions would give it a different meaning).  The obvious prediction is that there will be a direct to video Herbie movie down the road and that Lohan will be trying to find happiness and career success after leaving the Mouse behind.

reviewText: Before I start-A brief History of Herbie:We first saw Herbie, the volkswagon bug with a mind of its own in the car showroom of Peter Thorndyke (David Tomlinson) in "The Love Bug" released in 1968. Herbie, due to be sent away by Thorndyke was discovered by Jim Douglas (Dean Jones) who would race Herbie in several races. "The Love Bug" Special Edition is now available on DVD.In the sequel "Herbie Rides Again" (1974) we discover that Herbie is no longer racing with Jim Douglas. He is now with a sweet old lady called Mrs Steinmetz (played by veteran actress Helen Hayes) who he helps to protect from a corrupt developer. "Herbie Rides Again" is now available on DVD.Herbie returns yet again in "Herbie Goes To Monte Carlo" (1977). Reunited with Jim Douglas from "The Love Bug", Herbie's tasks this time include stopping some diamond thieves and winning the big Monte Carlo race. "Herbie Goes To Monte Carlo" is now available on DVD.The fourth classic movie "Herbie Goes Bananas"(1980) has Herbie becoming involved in various escapades in Mexico, on his way to a big race. It's a tough adventure for Herbie who gets very damaged before being cleaned up at the end. The big race does not happen in the movie, and it doesn't feature Jim Douglas either. "Herbie Goes Bananas" is now available on DVD.Then in 1982, there was the short-lived 5 episode television series "Herbie, The Love Bug". This featured Herbie on various adventures with his original owner Jim Douglas. The series hasn't been released on DVD as yet.Lastly there was the 1997 tv movie based on the original Herbie film, also called "The Love Bug". In it Herbie is passed onto a new owner by the name of Hank Cooper (Bruce Campbell). Together they must race against a dastardly racer and his evil car (named Horace) which has been built using the essence of Herbie. In this version of "The Love Bug", Herbie is virtually destroyed by Horace. Herbie even has a funeral and is thought of as gone forever, until Jim Douglas (Dean Jones) makes a surprise appearance. Jim Douglas and Herbie's original creator help to rebuild Herbie for another (grudge) race. And that was the last time we saw Herbie. "The Love Bug (1997) was previously available on VHS video.Now we have "Herbie Fully Loaded", the fifth big screen movie, and the fun is back and he can do more stunts than ever. This movie follows the pretty regular formula of car wins race, car loses race, car wins race again, car falls in love with another car- and you know what, that formula still works for Herbie- if you're a fan. If you're a newcomer to Herbie, you may find the movie underwhelming.Lindsay Lohan does a fine job in her role of our young female racer who races Herbie at Nascar. Michael Keaton does a fine job too as the father, as does Matt Dillon as the villain. There are also nice little special effects that enhance Herbie's skill, but nothing too ridiculous. These kind of special effects were only briefly used in the 1997 tv movie "The Love Bug", so to most people they'll seem pretty new here. There's also been rumor in the press that Lindsay Lohan herself has been digitally altered, but it was kind of hard to tell. I guess you'll have to watch "Mean Girls" to do a comparison. And as usual Herbie does get beaten up a little bit- at a monster rally- just enough reason for us to see the all-new Nascar Herbie. And as a sidenote, it was nice to see the Walt Disney Pictures logo return with the blue background and the castle- I'm glad it's back.In conclusion, Herbie Fully Loaded is a good movie, but it could have been better. Still, it's funny, I liked it, and it's a worthy addition to the Herbie series.

reviewText: The original Herbie movies made the lovable Volkswagen Beetle a family favorite in the 1960s and 1970s.  Disney's appetite for family friendly movies generated this movie, updated significantly for current audiences.  In an attempt to appeal to audiences of all ages, Lindsey Lohan ("Freaky Friday (2003)" and "Parent Trap (1998)"), Michael Keaton ("Beetlejuice" and "Batman") and Matt Dillon ("Rumble Fish" and "There's Something about Mary") star in this movie, in addition to the number 53 car, Herbie.Maggie Peyton (Lohan) has just graduated from college and she gets a beat up Volkswagen Beetle, vintage 1963, instead of the hot sports car she planned to get.  As Maggie keeps trying to get rid of the car, the car charms Maggie with its magical antics.  Maggie finally realizes that Herbie is the car for her, even as she aspires to become a NASCAR driver.Ray Peyton, Sr. (Keaton) does not want Maggie driving.  Ray is afraid that Maggie will get hurt in a racing accident.  Ray, Sr. has pinned his hopes on Ray, Jr. (Breckin Meyer; "The Craft" and "Kate and Leopold").  However, Ray, Jr. wants to be in a rock and roll band.  Guess what Ray?  Everyone wants to be in a rock and roll band.  Anyway, Maggie manages to sneak in some illicit racing by hiding her face and becoming "Max."  That disguise lasts long enough for Ray, Sr. to become really upset with Maggie.Maggie's nemesis is Trip Murphy (Dillon), who is arrogant and stuck up, though he is a good racer.  Trip has a number of issues, but Maggie will straighten Trip's issues out if she can beat him in a race.  Stay tuned for the end of the race as the lovable bug charms a new generation of viewers.The current Herbie retains some of the charm of the original.  The special effects wizards at Disney provided additional special effects that allow Herbie to be expressive.  Herbie's headlights move and general look like eyes.  Herbie's bumper also moves to provide additional characterization.  The one thing I missed from the original was the little noises that Herbie made in the original.  Herbie has very complex sounds, as discussed in one of the DVD extras, but the original Herbie had a lot of character in vocal effects.Keeping in the tradition of the original Love Bug, this movie is very family friendly and is suitable for all audiences.Included on the DVD are a host of extras.  The bloopers portion showed that Lindsay Lohan had to put up with a lot of practical jokes on the set.  There are deleted scenes, several features on how the movie was made, a music video starring Lohan, and an audio commentary track.  Many of the extras I thought were interesting.This movie is a reasonably good value and a good addition to a collection of family movies or a collection of Disney movies.  Enjoy!

Luckily for him, a beautiful, young college grad named Maggie Peyton arrives at the last minute in search of a car to use around town until she leaves California for an assistant producer job with ESPN in New York. The car is a graduation gift from her father, Ray Peyton Sr., who is busting with pride that his daughter is the first member of the famous Peyton racing family to graduate from college and move on to better things. Maggie's mind is still on racecars, however, an interest she promised her father she'd given up since having a minor car accident some time ago. Pickings are pretty slim at Crazy Dave's though, and fate, with a little effort on Herbie's part, lands the little Volkswagen bug in Maggie's less than thrilled hands.When Maggie finally takes Herbie for a drive, she finds the little car uncontrollable. Herbie conveniently drives her into the nearby auto shop of Maggie's old friend, Kevin. The young man is thrilled to see Maggie again, though she is wary of getting back in touch with her old street racing buddies against her father's wishes. As Maggie vows to return her new little car to the junkyard, Kevin hastily offers to fix Herbie up himself. It's his desperate way of making sure he will continue to see her. She agrees to allow him to try, and the two go for a short test drive. Herbie takes control again, of course, and drives the young couple directly to a local racing expo where Nextel Cup champion Trip Murphy happens to be signing autographs. When arrogant celebrity Trip throws one insult too many in Herbie's direction, the little car takes his revenge by scratching the side of Trip's car with his mirror. This leads to a street race that wows all onlookers, as Herbie employs some skateboarding skills he learned by watching Maggie to take the win! From then on, Trip becomes obsessed with defeating the little car and its driver, whose identity is a secret to everyone but Kevin. The driver, of course, is the reluctant Maggie, who manages to keep her secret with the help of a racing suit and helmet found in Herbie's trunk. In his quest for a rematch, Trip arranges a major racing event in which the final winner will go up against his own car, the prize being $10,000. As expected, Maggie and Kevin show up with a pimped out Herbie and win the shot at the money. Things go awry, however, when Trip and Maggie secretly raise the stakes, racing for each other's car as well. Maggie's brother, painfully unskilled racecar driver Ray Peyton Jr., gets injured just before the Nextel Championship race! It's a race the Peytons MUST win in order to hold on to their last remaining sponsors. Now, if Maggie does manage to save Herbie's life at the demolition derby, she also may be the only one who can race for Team Peyton to win the Nextel Cup!"Herbie: Fully Loaded" is nothing less than the BEST family film I've seen in a long while! I'm a longtime Herbie fan who owns all the Herbie films that have come before it (still waiting for the TV series and Bruce Campbell TV sequel to come to DVD, guys), just read my reviews for all the sequels and the original "Love Bug" film! Having said that, I must say that this sequel tops `em all, nearly coming out as good as the original! Sure, Herbie gets some changes in this film, but by the end, he looks pretty much like his old self with a few NASCAR modifications. And, when it comes to his personality, he's all Herbie! In fact, he's more lively and expressive than ever before, with headlight eyes that move about and blink, and the ability to smile and frown, and even do that "shaking water off like a dog" bit the original "Love Bug" makers so badly wanted to include in the first Herbie classic but couldn't figure out how. What keeps Herbie looking like Herbie though, is that he very rarely incorporates CGI effects! In fact, I think there may have been more blatant CGI Herbie footage in the Bruce Campbell TV movie, which this film pretty much ignores, though it thankfully manages to pay tribute to all the big screen sequels in a wonderful opening montage! Another important aspect of all the past Herbie films that "Fully Loaded" respectfully remembers to include (no, I don't mean the oil gag, though that's in here too) is the all important Herbie theme music! I gotta say, when I heard that music start playing in the movie theater, I think I teared up! The plot is far better than some folks would have you believe. Perhaps it is formulaic, but it's also wonderfully and cleverly written, with great, involving, and believable characters you can't help but love. Of course, this is enhanced by one of the two essentials of a great Herbie movie, a fantastic cast. First, there must be a great lead behind the wheel, and Lindsay Lohan isn't one of the biggest stars around today for nothing. She's also one of the most beautiful actresses out there today, especially in this film, with her fiery red hair and fantastically non-waifish figure. She's got the kind of feisty and strong personality one would expect in a female NASCAR driver. In the sidekick mechanic role, played in the past by the likes of Buddy Hackett, Don Knotts, Charles Martin Smith, and Kevin J. O'Connor, "Herbie: Fully Loaded" gives us Justin Long, a young actor I have always found to be nothing less than hilarious! He's a great choice for this film, not only taking over the mechanic position, but that of the lead's love-interest as well, which makes for some charming "budding romance" scenes. Of course, Herbie is always eager to lend love a helping hand, and he doesn't slack off in this entry either. This is an all-star cast, in fact, with Matt Dillon playing the heavy! He's absolutely, delightfully evil as the egotistical Trip Murphy. We also get the great Michael Keaton in the role of Ray Peyton Sr., and Breckin Meyer as Ray Peyton Jr., two actors that never disappoint. Cheryl Hines, Thomas Lennon, Jimmi Simpson, and cutie-pie Jill Ritchie round out the main cast beautifully, and for the real racing fans, there are plenty of great cameos from the likes of Jeff Gordon and Jimmie Johnson, among others! As for the other essential ingredient in a great Herbie film, yes, there are plenty of mind-boggling Herbie stunts, both new and old! "Herbie: Fully Loaded" was lovingly directed by Angela Robinson, as anyone could tell by watching with the audio commentary turned on, and it's a masterpiece when it comes to good, clean, but still marvelously entertaining family filmmaking! None of those crass, "adult" jokes hidden within this film, even if some of the lyrics to Lohan's "First" song from the soundtrack can get a bit too "racy." The soundtrack within the context of the film, though, is another wonderful treat! Lots of great retro tunes like "Magic," "Walking on Sunshine," and "More Than a Feeling."On DVD, "Herbie: Fully Loaded" looks great in widescreen and comes with a nice pile of extras. You get a featurette on NASCAR driving with racer Deborah Renshaw which also shows some of the actors learning the ins and outs of the job, another featurette on the stunts of "Herbie: Fully Loaded," and yet another on how Herbie is brought to life onscreen. There's a great blooper reel and some cool deleted scenes, including a fun animated opening that was rightfully rejected in favor of a more enlightening montage of Herbie's glory days and downward slide. There's also the aforementioned director commentary and the music video for Lindsay's song, "First." It's a cute video, but it also sadly illustrates how much more appealing and unique Lindsay looked as a curvy redhead(she's gone skinny blonde in the video). "Herbie: Fully Loaded" is a wonderful new addition to Disney's "Love Bug" legacy, bringing Herbie back with a cleverly modern scenario that doesn't sacrifice the wholesome and lovable qualities that carry through the little bug's long history. This is truly a film Disney should be proud of and all Disney fans should have on their shelves! And, if you love this film, be sure to check out the 4 feature films that came before it and the made-for-TV sequel starring Bruce Campbell, only available on VHS. I've written reviews for them all!

reviewText: Though corny and often silly, 'Herbie: Fully Loaded' is not a bad film as you may think.  I find the film fairly amusing, if not original, and surely Disney knows this is a family-oriented film, made for entertainment.So 'Herbie: Fully Loaded' is a sequel to (not a remake of) the previous 'Love Bug' films, and again the 'live' Volkswagen, now forgotten by people and left in the junkyard, is 'saved' by Lindsay Lohan's character Maggine Peyton, a wannabe NASCAR driver.  Soon Maggie finds out the incredible ability of this supercar called 'Herbie,' most of which are slapstick kind of things like spitting out oil over the face of the arrogant celebrity racer (and baddie) played by Matt Dillon.The story is that silly and predictable, but somehow it works as long as the film keeps showing Lindsay Lohan on screen.  Lohan's cute and nice girl image is intact here, and Walt Disney Pictures is well aware that their newer 'Love Bug' film needs her charms as the heroine we can relate to.  She succeeds, or shines if I may say, but of course, some might dislike the film exactly because she is there.  But anyway those Lohan haters would not see this film.Beside Matt Dillon, the film features supporting actors including Michael Keaton, Justin Long, Breckin Meyer, Jill Ritchie, and Cheryl Hines.  Sadly, however, none of them are not required to do much, except very good Justin Long as shy and good-natured mechanic, and the role of Breckin Meyer as Maggie's brother is too small for him.The car race scenes including the rousing finale are clearly helped by ILM's special effects, and the car often drives in the most ridiculous way (at times it slides as if skateboarding, and can move its doors like ... er ... a bug), but the film surely knows what it is doing. reviewText: This reboot tries hard to copy the originals. In my opinion, it fails miserably.Herbie - Fully Loaded has more plot holes than Star Trek. Peyton's dad should have at least grounded her for lying to him about racing. Instead all he does is walk away. There is no way a professional NASCAR driver would race an amateur in a VW Beetle. There is no way a demolition derby would let someone run out onto the track during a match. There is no way NASCAR would let a VW Beetle race there. Especially when it's a soft-top with no number on top (as per their regulations).But I think the biggest plot hole in this movie is that in this world of professional racing, no one recognized Herbie, even tho they found him in a shed full of racing trophies.The parts of the movie that aren't just bad are merely Disney's attempt to reheat famous scenes from old Herbie movies (The Love Bug, Herbie Rides Again, Herbie Goes Bananas, Herbie Goes to Monte Carlo) in the hope that we'll start watching again. The problem I have (in addition to the badly written, warmed-over plot) is that Maggie Peyton did not have to work her way up to the top, as did Jim Douglas.But that's the trouble with Disney for the last 15 years. Teens are shown that they deserve to be at the top without doing anything to earn it themselves. Peyton's dad buys her the car. Then Peyton gets to race against the top dog in NASCAR and win, even though Herbie is still fresh from the junkyard and is clearly illegal to drive.Then they clean Herbie up and slap on some cool stuff, as if it's supposed to improve his performance. But the whole point of Herbie movies is that Herbie performs better than souped up race cars because he has a heart. In adding all that stuff to Herbie, they pull his heart out - and mine too.If this isn't enough, Disney continues to beat us over the head with their "teens deserve to win without putting any effort into it" attitude by letting Maggie Peyton run out into a life-threatening demolition derby to get Herbie back, and then drive off with him without having to pay or sign any papers (Titles of Ownership are not transferred like sticks of gum).Then her Dad's pit crew comes and fixes Herbie good as new in a single night. Finally, Peyton gets to race in the Indy 500 without even having to qualify. Someone (her brother) does that for her, too. All Maggie Peyton does throughout the entire movie is sit behind the wheel screaming while others do everything for her.Did this make me want to watch new movies from Disney? No. It made me long for the originals. Disney needs to go back to yesteryear - not to copy it, but to recapture the magic they've lost by using no-talent bimbos in pale imitations of their original works.
summary: This is both original and good. Unfortunately, what is original is not good, and what is good is not original.

reviewText: OK, it's a mindless bit of amusement in which Lindsay Lohan follows her true love: stock car racing. It's a nice, safe plot in which the heroic teens overcome the evil forces of the ego-laden stock car racer. The big moral of the story is that a college education is OK and everything, but driving cars is really cool.Given that Lindsay is supposed to be this wicked awesome, fearless race driver, she spends an awful lot of time behind the wheel screaming. Well, I guess that's supposed to remind us that she's a girl, as if the sub-mini skirts and well-filled T-shirts weren't clues enough. Michael Keaton puts in a good performance, as he always does. And, as always, his performance is utterly unlike any of his others.It's kid-safe (no real violence, people keep their clothes on, etc.) but your tween-ager is likely to find it unsophisticated.
